title: 107_s2000
content: Special depreciation allowance available for certain property acquired between December 31, 2001, and January 1, 2004. Special allowance for qualified property acquired between December 31, 2001, and January 1, 2004, allows for a 30% depreciation deduction of the adjusted basis of the property in the year it is placed in service. The special allowance allows for a 30% depreciation deduction for qualified property acquired between December 31, 2001, and January 1, 2004. Qualified property includes property with a recovery period of 20 years or less, water utility property, computer software eligible for deduction under section 167(a), qualified leasehold improvement property, or property eligible for depreciation. The special allowance allows for a 30% depreciation deduction for qualified property acquired between December 31, 2001, and January 1, 2004, with specific eligibility criteria outlined. The special allowance provides a 30% depreciation deduction for qualified property acquired between December 31, 2001, and January 1, 2004, or January 1, 2005 for certain property with longer production periods. The special allowance offers a 30% depreciation deduction for qualified property acquired between December 31, 2001, and January 1, 2004. Transportation property subject to section 263A by certain clauses is eligible for an additional allowance based on pre-January 1, 2004, basis. The term 'transportation property' refers to tangible personal property used in the trade or business of transporting persons or property. Exceptions include property subject to the alternative depreciation system and listed property with limited business use. The subsection provides special rules for self-constructed property, stating that if a taxpayer begins manufacturing, constructing, or producing property for their own use after December 31, 2001, certain requirements will be treated as met. The subsection provides special rules for self-constructed property, stating that if a taxpayer begins manufacturing, constructing, or producing property for their own use after December 31, 2001, certain requirements will be treated as met. Sale-leasebacks of property originally placed in service after December 31, 2001, are subject to specific timing rules. For qualified leasehold improvement property, the Secretary will increase the limitation for passenger automobiles by $4,600 under section 280F. The deduction for listed property will be considered in calculating any recapture amount under section 280F. The term 'improvement property' refers to nonresidential real property improvements made under a lease, exclusively occupied by the lessee, and placed in service more than 3 years after the building was first placed in service. The term 'improvement property' excludes certain improvements such as building enlargement, elevators, escalators, structural components for common areas, and internal structural framework. Binding commitment to lease is considered a lease for tax purposes. For tax purposes, a lease between related persons is not considered a lease. Related persons include members of an affiliated group and individuals with a relationship described in section 267(b), with '80 percent or more' substituted for 'more than 50 percent'. The text discusses the qualification of leasehold improvement property and an allowance against alternative minimum tax under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The deduction under section 168(k) for property acquired between December 31, 2001, and January 1, 2004, is allowed. A conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. These amendments apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2001.
